channel.title: Digg Features - Digg
channel.description: Digg Features on Digg: the best articles, videos, tweets, and original content that the web is talking about right now

item.title: This Twitter Thread Of Animals That Look Like Pokémon Might Be The Most Delightful Thing You See Today
item.description: Rebecca Helm, a biology professor at the University of North Carolina Asheville who specializes in jellyfish, put together an eye-popping Twitter thread of real world animals that she deemed "should be Pokemon."

item.title: Oh, You Know New York? Name All Of Its 288 Neighborhoods
item.description: A Reddit user created an interactive map that defines no fewer than 288 neighborhoods among its boroughs. That is so many more neighborhoods than we thought there were.
item.kicker: THE CITY LIMIT DOES NOT EXIST

item.title: This Week's Top Memes, Ranked
item.description: It's an internet fight and only the top memes will survive. This week's challengers: Gifted kids, missing the bus, the latest TikTok trend and more.

item.title: All Of September 2019, In One Big Post
item.description: As summer came to an end, the online content did not. These are 10 of the most popular and important stories from the last month, as determined by Digg readers.

item.title: All Of August In One Big Post
item.description: Lots of good and bad stuff happened on the internet this month. Shockingly, even *more* stuff fell in between.

item.title: 'I've Seen The Worst In Humanity': The Hard Reality Of Being A Brand Social Media Manager
item.description: "The worst has to be death threats or threats of sexual violence with really graphic footage."

item.title: All Of July 2019 In One Big Post
item.description: Man, it's a hot one. A hot month for weird internet content, that is. Here are the ten stories from July that mattered most on Digg.

item.title: The Most Sincere Man On The Internet
item.description: The surreal online life of James White, a young Chinese man with one of the most disarmingly sincere presences on the internet.

item.title: What Happens After MoviePass
item.description: After switching to the AMC Stubs A-List service, I found myself, for some reason, going to the movies less than before.

item.title: 'Sailor Moon' And The Queer History Of Anime Transformations
item.description: How a clever technique to save money on animation costs helped queer audiences feel empowered by who they are.
item.kicker: ONCE IN A BLUE MOON CRYSTAL POWER

item.title: Is It Still Okay To Use The OK Hand Emoji?
item.description: Emojis have never existed in a political vacuum, and as more hand gestures are becoming increasingly politicized, so are the usage of their emojis.

item.title: Everyone Needs A Home Away From The Internet, Of The Internet
item.description: How XOXO, a beloved festival for internet creators, affected a disillusioned mope like me.
item.kicker: WHERE THE NET'S NOT SO BAD

item.title: Does Disney Hate Cats?: Searching For The Common Animal Villains In The Disney Universe
item.description: When it comes to the animal villains in Disney movies, data shows some animals are far more likely to play the antagonist than others.

item.title: The Irrelevance Of Rotten Tomatoes Scores When It Comes To TV Shows
item.description: Rotten Tomatoes does assign scores to TV shows — as do other sites such as IMDB and TV.com — but why does nobody ever talk about them?

item.title: Why A Million People Follow A Woman Who Says She's Channeling The Archangels
item.description: Melanie Beckler says she has a special connection to heavenly beings. And with her help, you too can access the infinite wisdom of the archangels, all for a low monthly payment of $37.

item.title: I Say LOL, You Say Ek 1: How People Around The World Laugh Online
item.description: Some differences are easier to parse, like the French "héhéhé." Others phrases, such as the Brazilian "kkk" and the Russian "xoxoxo," however, may be baffling or startling to an English speaker at first glance.

item.title: I Explored The World Of Japanese Dating Apps And It's Even More Different Than I Imagined
item.description: From ranking users by popularity to including blood types in profiles, Japanese dating apps are different from American dating apps in many fascinating ways.

item.title: I Forced Myself To Watch Netflix Original Movies For A Month. Here's What I Learned
item.description: Netflix often claims to recommend movies according to an user's viewing history, but when it comes to its original movies, there are some titles it clearly prioritizes over others.

item.title: How Chinese Users Navigate An Internet Dominated By Censorship
item.description: When it comes to accessing news of a sensitive nature, Chinese users have a distinctive way of using the internet that is different from other web users around the world.

item.title: Why Do Movie Franchises Keep Getting Longer?
item.description: As blockbuster franchises continue to hit us with prequels, sequels and spinoffs that seem to challenge our bladder strength, we want to know whether it's a truth or a misconception that franchises are growing longer with each new movie.

item.title: Why Tech Founders Get Hot
item.description: Last July, the internet ignited in a fit of erotic-capitalistic ecstasy. No, it wasn't because of Pornhub's net neutrality protest or the latest teledildonics patent lawsuit. Instead, the virtual pulsation was caused by the bulging biceps of the world's richest man.

item.title: Will The 'Three Billboards' Oscars Backlash Make It This Year's 'La La Land'?
item.description: The problematic portrayals of race and violence in "Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri" has muddied the movie's Best Picture prospects these past months.

item.title: What Would Happen If You Microwaved A Microwave?
item.description: Is it the dividing-by-zero catastrophe everyone hopes it is, or is it nothing more than just putting a metal box inside of a smaller metal box?

item.title: What Would Happen If You Never Took Your Earbuds Out?
item.description: How long have you left your earbuds in today? A couple hours? Well, what if you just never took them out?
item.kicker: THEY WOULD RUB YOU THE WRONG WAY

item.title: How To Brew Coffee At Home Like A Gosh Darn Adult
item.description: It seems intimidating, but making your own coffee will save you money, give you a satisfying morning ritual and bring you one step closer to being a fully autonomous adult.

item.title: Words Of Wisdom From Chess Grandmaster Maurice Ashley
item.description: Digg had the honor of sitting down with Maurice Ashley, an International Grandmaster of chess, to learn how chess-playing skills can translate into life-playing skills. Learn how chess masters size up their opponents and problems, push through failure, and ultimately become power players in the real world.

item.title: How Magicians Trick Your Brain: The Psychology Of Magic
item.description: We know magic tricks aren't real, yet we continue to be fooled and impressed by them time after time. So how do magicians still manage to keep audiences on their toes? They mess with our brains of course!

item.title: Choosing The Perfect Plant For Your Home
item.description: It's not always clear which plants to buy, where to put them or even how to keep them alive. Thankfully, Christopher Satch, the in-house plant specialist at The Sill, is here to pass along his knowledge to you.

item.title: Essential Reading On The Anniversary Of 9/11
item.description: Eighteen years after the start of the "Post 9/11 World," we still struggle to make sense of such an event, and continue to feel the shockwaves and consequences it gave rise to. Here, we've selected works that we believe best illuminate and unravel the vast implications of that day.
